metadata.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Kharbanda

facts.text: Sen Tribunal appointed in June 1949 for bank disputes; award set aside by Supreme Court in 1951; Act II of 1951 froze certain provisions.
Sastry Tribunal appointed in January 1952; award published April 20, 1953; Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed with modifications on April 28, 1954.
Sastry Award provided one scale for clerks in Class A, Area I: Rs. 85 to Rs. 280 (para 119); special allowance of Rs. 50/- for supervisors in A class banks, Area I (para 164).

Sastry Award para 292(7) for employees joining after January 31, 1950: fitted into new scale point-to-point as though in force since joining, provided adjusted basic pay not less than under point-to-point on corresponding pre-Sen scale.
Respondent appointed as supervisor on April 22, 1951, basic salary Rs. 120/- per mensem; pre-Sastry supervisor scale: Rs. 120-8-200-EB-10-300.
Appellant fixed respondent's basic salary using graduate clerks scale (highest Rs. 120/-), not supervisors scale.
Respondent claimed entitlement to Rs. 6,428.28 nP. arrears if basic salary correctly fixed under Sastry Award.
Respondent applied to Central Labour Court, Delhi under s. 33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act in L.C.A. No. 80 of 1960; Labour Court decided in favour of respondent on August 2, 1960.
Industrial tribunal award on April 4, 1957 held supervisors as workmen; affirmed by Supreme Court in Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen.
Appellant bank had nine scales for workmen; six for clerical staff including supervisors.

legal_issues.text: Whether application under s. 33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act is maintainable for computation of monetary benefit under Sastry Award where dispute exists on calculation.
Correct method to fix basic salary under Sastry Award para 292(7): whether using supervisors scale or clerks scale as corresponding pre-Sen scale.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application not maintainable under s. 33C(2) as it applies only to non-monetary benefits capable of being converted to money.
Basic salary fixation correct using highest point on graduate clerks scale as corresponding; supervisors not separate clerks scale.

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to benefits under Sastry Award; s. 33C(2) applies to any benefit capable of computation, including monetary where disputed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act; prior tribunal decisions

respondent_arguments.text: Basic salary to be fixed using pre-Sen supervisors scale as corresponding workmen's scale; supervisors are workmen.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sastry Award para 292(7); Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen

court_reasoning.text: s. 33C(2) applies to any benefit capable of being computed in terms of money, including monetary benefits where computation disputed (e.g., under award); not limited to non-monetary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Benefit' includes monetary advantage; 'computed' means calculate, not 'converted'; contrasts with s. 33C(1).

court_reasoning.text: Corresponding pre-Sen scale for respondent is supervisors scale as it was workmen's scale; Sastry Award unifies clerical workmen scales; special allowance irrelevant for basic pay fixation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cl. 7 relates to corresponding grades of workmen by whatever name; supervisors held workmen between parties.

holdings.text: Application under s. 33C(2) maintainable for computation of disputed monetary benefit under award.
Basic pay fixed point-to-point on supervisors pre-Sen scale; not reduced below that under new scale.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen

precedents_cited.relevance: s. 20 Appellate Tribunal Act (similar to s. 33C(2)) not limited to non-monetary benefits

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Provision for computation and recovery of benefits under awards/settlements

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act, 1945
statutes_cited.relevance: Finally settled bank disputes; Sastry Award provisions unmodified

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Predecessor provision similar to s. 33C for execution

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Labour Court correct in holding application maintainable under s. 33C(2) and in favouring respondent's salary fixation on supervisors scale; amount due undisputed once principle fixed.
outcome.relief_granted: Respondent entitled to arrears as computed on correct basic salary fixation

key_quotes.text: 'The word benefit is of wide import, and the dictionary meaning thereof is advantage, profit. This would naturally include monetary advantage or monetary profit.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'The word in the qualifying clause is computed and the dictionary meaning of the word compute is merely to calculate.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes 'computed' from 'converted'; allows monetary benefits if computation disputed

key_quotes.text: 'What the Sastry award did was to make one grade for all clerical workmen and when cl. 7 speaks of correspondence it relates in our opinion to the corresponding grades of workmen by whatever name they may have been known in particular banks.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
